abstract.p: Irene Z Schwartz letter on July 26 article on Badlands National Park in South Dakota recalls memories of trips to other national parks (S)

block.p: The July 26 article ''Alone in the Badlands,'' about the South Dakota National Park, brought back memories of our visit. My husband and I are national park ''collectors'' and have visited almost all, from A for Acadia to Z for Zion.

Badlands is only one of many ''lonely places.'' The two parks in Texas, Big Bend and Guadalupe Mountains, remain undiscovered. Route 62 runs through a small corner of Guadalupe and is its only paved road. A very small part is accessible by four-wheel-drive vehicles and the rest by foot. Big Bend has paved roads but apparently its location and desertlike heat keep crowds away.

The July 26 article ''Alone in the Badlands,'' about the South Dakota National Park, brought back memories of our visit. My husband and I are national park ''collectors'' and have visited almost all, from A for Acadia to Z for Zion.

Badlands is only one of many ''lonely places.'' The two parks in Texas, Big Bend and Guadalupe Mountains, remain undiscovered. Route 62 runs through a small corner of Guadalupe and is its only paved road. A very small part is accessible by four-wheel-drive vehicles and the rest by foot. Big Bend has paved roads but apparently its location and desertlike heat keep crowds away.
Perhaps the most unpeopled park we have visited is Channel Isles, about 25 miles off Ventura, Calif.
IRENE Z. SCHWARTZ East Meadow, N.Y.
